1. Technical support to Countries implementing HIV programmes supported by UNAIDS country envelope funding to 13 countries in ESA and 14 countries in WCA.

In 2019 most countries in WCA and ESA reported substantive results related to delivery under the 2019 UBRAF (UNAIDS) Country Envelop grants. - Tanzania: Tanzania is finalized their zonal Key and Vulnerable Population (KVP) policy dialogues. Deliverables of the dialogues supported the country to prepare processes for the new GFATM country application in 2020. - Chad: After several consultations with stakeholders including the government through the Ministry of Justice in charge of human rights, the workshop of the technical revision and technical validation of the preliminary draft Law supplementing Law No. 19 / PR / 2007 of 15 November 2007 on the fight against HIV / AIDS / STI and protection of the rights of people living with HIV / AIDS was finalized for 24 to 27 November 2019 with about fifty participants and will absorb the entire UBRAF fund granted to UNDP Chad. - DR Congo Capacity building on legal, judicial and psychosocial support, HIV, SHR, Human rights, and gender for lawyers, social assistants and judges, medical doctors was conducted and 32 officers of judiciary and lawyers sensitised -Kenya conducted consultations and national dialogues on HIV, human rights and the law,
1. Technical support to Countries implementing HIV programmes supported by UNAIDS country envelope funding to 13 countries in ESA and 17 countries in WCA.

In 2020, in sub-Saharan Africa, UNDP supported 17 countries in West and Central Africa and 12 countries in Eastern & Southern Africa and enabled governments, civil societies, national institutions and regional economic entities to deliver on UNDP’s portfolio on HIV, health and development (HHD). In addition, UNDP’s Africa HHD Team supported 32 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa to access Rapid Response Facility (RRF) funds for UNDP’s Response 1.0 to combat effects of the COVID-19 pandemic that continues to sweep across the world since March 2020. The HHD Team has since followed up with supporting 46 sub-Saharan African countries to draft proposals for additional investment under COVID-19 Response 2.0 or the Response Funding Facility (RFF). As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic the Africa Team, together with the UNDP Global adapted new ways of remote working; moved from working out of dedicated office spaces to working from home, and substituted duty travel for online meetings via a range of digital platforms. It was a year of extreme changes and rapid adaptation to the extreme change to ensure that UNDP continued to deliver on its mandate and promise of Leaving No One Behind. During the year, several Country Offices from across sub-Saharan Africa reported on supporting national efforts to address COVID-19 pandemic and to continue to support national HIV/AIDS and TB interventions. In Angola UNDP with support of the regional Linking Policy with Programming (LPP) Project, the project’s National Steering Committee prioritised the review of the HIV Law 04/08 that covers critical areas related to prevention of stigma and discrimination, address inequalities in access to services, access to justice, human rights, health and SRHR. This will lead to additional review of issues around wilful transmission of HIV and the right to privacy (confidentiality within the health sector). Terms of reference have been developed and a committee established to lead the review process which will be completed in 2021 and expected to result in reading down or removal of the clause on wilful transmission of HIV. In addition, under the same project, UNDP supported legal literacy and Engagement Scan training for young key populations during the year. The training focused on human rights and implementation of the engagement scan tool with participants drawn from young key population activists and key population civil society organisations. The training underscored the importance of knowledge of laws and rights relevant to YKPs and their sexual and reproductive health; and increased the participants’ and their organisations’ capacities to engage in international law and policy reform processes. Over 30 young key population activists and KP organisations attended the training. In Burkina Faso, to strengthen the fight against stigma and discrimination in the context of HIV, COVID-19 and to address the humanitarian crisis, UNDP supported a range of interventions during the year designed to involve community actors in the implementation of COVID-19 awareness, communication and resilience interventions. • 60 customary religious leaders (54 men and 6 women) were capacitated to advocate against discriminating internally displaced persons (IDPs), including PLHIV displaced as a result of the health and humanitarian crisis that the country has been facing in the Centre-North and North regions—this resulted in forming a core base of resource people who are now supporting awareness-raising activities for better protection of populations including IDPs in these regions. • To strengthen community engagement for prevention and response to COVID-19, and to bolster social cohesion, UNDP supported the National Youth Council—that carried out community awareness activities as part of the “20_20 Battalion Initiative”, resulting in mobilising 3,370 young people including 899 young girls through 270 municipalities in the 13 regions. A total of 339 women leaders were engaged in sensitization that included 53 radio broadcasts on COVID-19 awareness. An additional 600 national volunteers were mobilised to raise awareness and promote barrier measures in Ouagadougou markets. Finally, 48 journalists (including 14 women) were trained on COVID-19 issues to better contribute to raising awareness of barrier measures for infection control against COVID-19. • Through the RRF intervention, prevention and protection measures were made available to poorer and vulnerable populations: 300,000 masks were distributed among 170,000 women and 130,000 men; and 850 young people were trained in hydroalcoholic gel manufacturing. • Mechanisms to access low-value/small grants were made available to three NGOs engaged in community response to COVID-19, and finally, • UNDP supported the design of a project that will support the role of women leaders in the COVID-19 response. Trainings focused on designing bankable projects and on digitization are ongoing for 200 women leaders in 4 regions of the country. In Central African Republic (CAR), UNDPs contribution made it possible to carry out a study of the impact of COVID-19 on the socio-economic situation to inform the drafting of government sector policies and helped to develop a comprehensive integrated intervention program, resulting in 500 young people supported in income-generating activities; 1,000 farming households benefiting from joint support from UNDP and FAO; and increased access to drinking water for the populations of Haut-Mbomou through building of 15 community infrastructures including 3 wells. The latest Stigma Index Survey in CAR showed that 87% of PLHIV (90.1%for women vs. 80% for men) report self-stigma. Overall, women living with HIV are more likely (49.2%) to “experience stigma and discrimination” than men living with HIV (37.1%). During the year, UNDP supported capacity-building of 30 PLHIV peer educators, 50% of whom are women, to develop skills to address stigma and discrimination; and on raising awareness of COVID-19 including the importance of non-pharmaceutical interventions including social distancing. UNDP also trained the peer educators on using personal protective equipment (PPE) and provided them with PPE to enable them to conduct outreach. This resulted in 5,000 people being reached and informed of the modes of transmission of COVID-19 and means of its prevention. Further, this outreach enabled 4,000 people in the community to access 4,000 screening test vouchers, of which 2,000 were utilised for getting tested. Finally, the 30 PLHIV peer educators and outreach workers benefited from a cash transfer to strengthen their income during the pandemic. In DR Congo, lockdown measures due to COVID-19 and related restrictions resulted in increased vulnerability of affected households, key and vulnerable populations, as well as people already affected by HIV, and increased their need for social and nutritional protection. Two rapid assessments, conducted by two community based organisations in Kinshasa (PSSP and UCOP+), with the aim of identifying problems and / or needs of PLHIV and key populations during this pandemic revealed that key issues facing PLHIV and those at risk of HIV during the pandemic included: (1) low availability of ARVs, estimated 40–60% of PLHIVs had stock of more than 2 months; (2) More than 85% PLHIV feared contracting COVID-19; (3) Persistence of barriers to care access (geographic, cultural and financial); (4) High exposure of sex workers, MSM and TG to various forms of violence during this period (rape, arrests, stigmatization and discrimination)—that threatened their survival; and (5) Difficulty in obtaining supplies of condoms, lubricants, etc. The studies resulted in a contingency plan focused at reducing the harmful effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the HIV / AIDS programme in the DRC. To support the plan, UNDP Country Office focused on interventions that: • Strengthened communication capacities of multisectoral coordination teams at national and provincial level by providing efficient remote communication equipment for videoconference meetings; • Enabled local production and distribution of hydroalcoholic solutions (in the absence of running water in some communities and in prisons) so that key and vulnerable populations had access to hygiene measures recommended for preventing COVID-19 transmission; • Supported local production of fabric masks by women living with HIV as a measure to mitigate the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 in this vulnerable segment of the population, (more than 100,000 masks made, at a cost of 2 $ / material purchase and labour); • Supported the establishment of a distribution mechanism for masks produced so that these could be distributed to key and vulnerable people without duplication, in partnership with local and provincial authorities; • Enabled the capacity building for 141 health care providers and community actors on human rights, gender, SRH in the context of COVID-19; • Supported the sensitization training of 542 community activists/peer educators—from PLHIV, SW, MSM and TG communities—to conduct awareness on the fight against stigma and discrimination, identification of sexual violence cases and all other forms of abuse among local communities—and to ensure mass and interpersonal communication on the risks associated with COVID-19; and • Supported strengthening HIV VCT in prisons and in sex worker, MSM and transgender sites combined with the distribution of condoms and lubricants. In Eswatini, UNDP supported the Commission on Human Rights and Public Administration to conduct assessments on the national COVID-19 response and on the implementation of the Sexual Offenses and Domestic Violence Act of 2018. The study to assess the implementation of the SODVA followed concerns that the Act was operationalised without relevant regulations and that bottlenecks have slowed the prosecution of cases. The study will result in recommendations on drafting regulations that will support implementation of the Act ensuring a human rights-based approach. In Ghana, UNDP partnered with the Ghana Health Service and strengthened risk communication and community engagements on COVID-19 for vulnerable populations including persons with disability, people living with HIV and the prisons in 160 districts. Till date 14,352 (8624 M, 5728F) persons with disability including the visually impaired, physically challenged, hearing impaired, mentally challenged and people suffering from leprosy from 160 districts across the country have been empowered with relevant COVID-19 information in disability-friendly formats (including braille and sign language) to prevent COVID-19 infection within their communities. In addition, 613 (266M 347F) persons living with HIV (PLHIV) have also been empowered with relevant information on hand hygiene, mask-wearing, respiratory etiquette and importance of ARV treatment adherence during the COVID-19 pandemic. During 2020, UNDP in Lesotho undertook supported research and analysis for Stigma Index 2.0 in collaboration with a coalition of partners including GNP+. Thirty-one young people (21 women and 10 men) were trained on data collection methodology, and 1 Researcher, 1 IT Specialist and 1 Local Coordinator (PLHIV) supported, mentored and supervised the data collectors who were recruited from among PLHIV (20), female sex workers (4), MSM and transgender (4) and ex-inmates (3). Given COVID-19, the researchers and data collectors were provided PPE. The Lesotho Stigma Index 2.0 assessment will result in a report that will lead advocacy and support evidence based programming to address stigma and discrimination, and inform reform of laws and policies for protecting and promoting rights of people living with and at higher risk of HIV. In Madagascar, with support of the LPP Project, UNDP supported the process to review the HIV law. Trainings for the HIV and Law Commission and Members of Parliament (Health Portfolio committee) on Human rights HIV and the law were conducted in preparation for the law reform. Madagascar has also produced a draft gender bill for consideration by the Parliament. UNDP, jointly with other UN agencies, continues to provide technical support to ensure that rights of vulnerable communities including key populations are not adversely affected by provisions related to same sex relations and same sex marriages and aims to follow up on the action during 2021. In Nigeria, during the year UNDP, as one of the members of a technical working group to support the Nigerian National Agency for Control of AIDS (NACA), facilitated inputs for a Gender and Human Rights perspective in the harmonized National KP guideline that is being developed to address needs of MSM, FSW, PWID, TG and for people in closed settings. The support incudes monitoring the gender and human rights progress nationally. During the year, as part of the Spotlight Initiative, UNDP Nigeria supporting strengthening of the national legal and policy framework that resulted in i) Strengthened capacities of 170 women’s and girls’ rights advocates to advocate for and support review, domestication, monitoring implementation of relevant laws and policies; ii) 342 Law Enforcement Officers, out of which half were women, trained to effectively contribute to the implementation of laws and policies on ending VAWG; iii) A policy framework developed that makes case for the continued and improved funding of the minimum core obligations of the State related to HIV prevention and prevention of sexual and gender-based violence, and improved access to SRHR for adolescent girls and young women; and also called for prioritising AGYG needs in the review of the 2020 Nigerian Federal Budget; iv) Participation of 33,190 persons in community programmes that promoted gender-equitable norms, attitudes and behaviours, including in relation to women’s and girls’ sexuality and reproductive needs and rights; and v) Directly reaching 17,510 persons through campaigns and interventions transforming negative social norms and gender stereotyping that promote VAWG/HP/SGBV; with an estimated 800,000 people who were reached through radio jingles and radio talk shows in local languages. Sierra Leone already has a Safety Net Scheme (supported by donors and the UN) for vulnerable populations, managed by the National Commission for Social Action (NaCSA) which provides nutritional support and/or cash transfers. However, most PLHIVs were excluded in the past, especially the most vulnerable PLHIVs. In collaboration with the WFP and with UBRAF funding, the Country Office supported a database to include all PLHIVs including those living in border communities. The survey will also ascertain the impact of COVID-19 on PLHIVs, and is expected to enhance appropriate decision-making regarding sustainable social services and protection interventions. Further, UNDP supported promoting rights of inmates in correctional centres during COVID-19 pandemic, when the UNDP Rule of Law unit supported to the Correctional Centres around the country that resulted in 17,000 face masks produced by the Sierra Leone Correctional Service through their tailoring section in Freetown. Twenty-five personnel and supervisors together with 40 inmates were engaged in the production of the face masks and livelihood skills were transferred to the inmates who were engaged in the process. Further, this support to the Correctional Services also strengthened the rehabilitation and reformation of WATSAN component of the Correctional Services for protection and prevention against the COVID-19 pandemic. For inmates, this resulted in, among other things, these proceeds forming a part of the Earning Scheme at the Freetown Pademba Road Correctional Centre. Additionally, since even simple cotton facemasks became hard to find or very expensive or of poor quality for most people following the onset of COVID-19, UNDP supported the production of an additional 18,000 cotton face masks to be distributed free to vulnerable populations in towns and cities as far as border communities far removed from the centre. Not only this resulted in ensuring mask use by people not able to get them easily, this also resulted in training 40 vulnerable adolescents (11 boys and 29 girls) to produce cotton face masks that they can produce later on and sell at reasonable price to ensure a source of income. To understand and address barriers faced by key populations in accessing HIV services as a result of COVID-19 restrictions, UNDP in Uganda supported a case documentation exercise to document and profile cases of PLHIV and KP suffering and socially excluded during the pandemic—across a range of issues and constituencies. The cases documented indicated that the suffering of PLHIV and KPs ranged from lack of access to medicine/ARVs, domestic violence, and discrimination at workplace. A total of 110 cases were documented that include 66 cases of GBV, 15 cases on lack of access to medicine and 1 case of discrimination at workplace. These cases represent a portion of how people living with HIV and Key Populations suffered during COVID-19. This evidence has been used to make a case for these groups in a number of fora including the National COVID-19 Task Force; and the evidence was used to address the gaps created by the COVID-19 lockdown directives that were not sensitive to the issues of vulnerable populations. As a result, a booklet is being compiled and designed for dissemination during the Annual National Dialogue on HIV and Human Rights that is slated for 10th December 2020 for advocacy purposes and as a call to action with duty bearers. Further, two dedicated programmes were hosted on two national radio stations: Radio one and KFM, to speak against all forms of cruel treatment KPs and people living with HIV suffer in public and private spaces, and the heightened stigma and discrimination they faced during COVID-19. A total of 40 spot messages were aired on each radio station to fight against vulnerabilities, stigma and discrimination. Additionally five social media influencers were engaged and a total of 50 written articles and 20 infographics on the suffering of PLHIV and KP in public and private spaces during COVID-19 were produced and used for engagement on social media. The 20 e-posters/infographics shared on social media steered conversation on violations people living with HIV and KPs are facing during COVID-19, and resulted in an increase in awareness and relevant authorities taking action to improve access of PLHIV and KPs to treatment and to legal support services. Continuing to support key populations during 2020, UNDP supported an implementing partner (IP) to rescue sex workers and PLHIV survivors of violence in both private and public sphere. The IP was able to rescue women survivors of violence in both private and public sphere during the COVID-19 lockdown where women’s safety was compromised. The rescued survivors of GBV were admitted to a rescue/shelter home for between 2 weeks to a month or more following an assessment of the counsellors and legal officers. A total of 86 survivors (51 adult women. 5 adolescent girls and 30 children) were rescued by the police and the IP’s frontline staff. On arrival at the shelter home, they were supported with wellness programs, access to healthcare, psychosocial counselling, legal support and skilling in handicrafts as well as agriculture. UNDP also supported UGANET to start a toll-free call centre in May 2020 serviced by 22 operators to attend calls 24*7, in 5 local languages and 6 foreign languages. Since it was set up a total of 506 people (348 women and 158 men) have been supported through the call centre to link up with legal and other relevant services. The cases reported ranged from gender-based violence, deprivation of HIV/TB services, maternal health complications, emergency health conditions, etc. Finally, UNDP supported the coordination of a network of responders from grassroots to national offices including community monitors and police responders during the lockdown that resulted in mobilising 25 community legal volunteers to respond to calls for support from KPs, PLHIV, women and girls who were abused in both public and private spaces and required legal redress and or safety away from those spaces. They also supported target populations who were in need of health care services by acquiring movement permits for them, delivering drugs/medications to their homes as well reporting cases of abuse to police on their behalf. In partnership with the police, 7 cases have been supported—including for defilement, unlawful confinement, domestic violence, attempted rape and child abuse. In all these cases the survivors were rescued by police and investigations for prosecution and ongoing. In Zimbabwe, UNDP supported the National Steering Committee on HIV, Human Rights and Health and the country’s key population forum to convene a virtual webinar to discuss the COVID-19 pandemic, which calls for countries to implement strategies like stringent lockdowns to the reduce transmission of infection. Such stringent measures may disproportionately affect certain groups and may even border on infringement of rights of citizens especially key populations and possibly reverse the gains made in the implementation of targeted programmes by the state and civil society organizations. The webinar discussed COVID-19 response programmes that include the use of health bio-data management in disease surveillance (contact-tracing), and infringe on the right to privacy and confidentiality especially in countries where same sex relationships, or sex work are criminalized, and how such information could be used post-COVID-19; increased stigma and discrimination; failure to apply social distancing in prisons; lack of access to COVID-19 testing sites; disruption or discontinued access to ART due to lockdown and selective closing down of certain health facilities and prioritizing HIV testing sites; and lack of access to SRHR services such as STI treatment. The meeting also discussed that COVID-19 may also create opportunities to promulgate and implement draconian laws that impinge on civil liberties across the region; and increased stigmatization and discrimination of migrants and certain populations. The webinar informed the final drafting of a COVID-19 policy brief due for finalising by end of 2020. It is based on addressing the issues discussed in the webinar, and global guidance on how to protect key populations, particularly young key populations from human rights violations in times of COVID-19. The policy brief focuses on addressing issues facing young key populations (primarily) under COVID-19 including (i) current barriers to access to health care services due to COVID-19 restrictions, inaccessibility of usual services, disruptions in services, breaches in confidentiality, stigma and discrimination against YKP etc; (ii) ‘targeting’ of key populations in enforcement of restrictions by law enforcers—unlawful arrests, arbitrary application of regulations, crackdowns on sex workers, increased fear of arrest amongst MSM; (iii) restrictions on freedom of movement on LGBTI populations, who are then forced into living with unsupportive families, and on sex workers who are unable to work etc; and (iv) the critical need for access to legal support services. During 2020, UNDP in DR Congo provided support to legal clinics in Kinshasa to assist victims of violence and other abuse (victims included women, adolescents and young people, and representatives from key population groups) linked to COVID-19 pandemic. The support led to the development of a web application to create a communication interface between civil society actors and users of legal clinics that facilitated collection and management of qualitative and quantitative data on the services offer and obtain cross-referenced and filtered data allowing rapid and efficient decision-making. Following the first results obtained in Kinshasa (where 109 people were successfully followed-up), the officials of the Ministries of Health and Justice have requested for open access to this tool to all legal clinics at the national level. This final process is ongoing and expected to be finalised by December 15, 2020. In addition, partnering with the KOICA and the South Korean University Hospital team, the DR Congo Country Office have set up a second diagnostic laboratory for COVID-19 and other epidemics within the University clinics of Kinshasa. This centre strengthens the country’s diagnostic capacity for COVID-19, and will, in the longer term, respond to DRC’s need for advanced diagnostics to respond to other epidemics as well. Equipped with state-of-art equipment and health professionals trained in molecular screening, the facility has the capacity to process 200 RT-PCR tests per day, or 18,000 tests in 3 months, and will effectively support the management of the health crises facing the country. Finally, during the year, UNDP in DR Congo supported building the capacity of 100 new magistrates and 50 lawyers in the courts and tribunals of Kinshasa, Kananga, Kalemie on HIV, human rights, gender and SRH. In Ghana, during the year, 227 (145M 82F) prison officials and wardens from various prisons across the country have been equipped with relevant knowledge, skills and tools on COVID-19 prevention. In addition, a module on COVID-19 prevention in the prisons has been developed to enhance COVID-19 prevention education within the prisons: actions which have resulted in increased awareness and implementation of measures to restrict/prevent COVID-19 transmission within Ghanaian prisons. In Lesotho, UNDP, through its Accelerator Lab developed and deployed a mobile application for Community Health Care workers to monitor suspected and quarantined cases of COVID-19 within their communities. The application facilitated community health surveillance and linked community level with district and national platforms ensuring seamless coordination. In its future iteration the application will be expanded to cover other public health issues such as HIV/AIDS among others. Over 1000 community health workers were trained in 4 out of 10 districts in use of the application. This initiative is the result of a successful public private partnership with private cell phone company ECONET, the Ministry of Health and UNDP. During the year, UNDP supported Zimbabwe to follow up on the national law reform agenda based on recommendations of the Zimbabwe legal environment assessment (LEA). Strong advocacy by the Zimbabwe National AIDS Council, together with CSOs and UN joint team on HIV and AIDS (UNJTA) resulted in a Parliamentary motion to repeal Section 79 (Wilful transmission of HIV) of the Criminal Code of Zimbabwe. Additional follow-up action during the year included a public hearing held on 12 November 2020, aimed at sensitising Parliamentarians to review current age of consent laws that prevent young people from accessing sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services, with the aim of facilitating access of young people to SRH services through law/policy reform in 2021. Regionally during the year UNDP with regional resources from Global Fund, supported the finalization, endorsement and publication of the “2020-2025 Regional Strategy for HIV, Tuberculosis, Hepatitis B&C and Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights among Key Populations in the Economic Community of West African States”. The strategy was developed by the West African Health Organization (WAHO), with support from UNDP, working with WHO, UNAIDS, UNFPA and other partners. This report, which was presented formally by the WAHO Chairperson during the AIDS2020 Virtual, will guide, harmonize and drive scale-up of regional and national responses for key populations in the ECOWAS region—a region where the HIV and AIDS epidemic primarily affects key populations (sex workers and their partners, MSM, transgender people, PWID, prisoners and migrants). Continentally, during November 2020, UNDP participated in the AIDS Watch Africa (AWA) Consultative Experts’ Meeting (virtual) convened by the African Union Commission. The meeting was attended by more than a hundred people in the first day and around 75 people in the second day. While the initial draft report circulated by the AUC did not include any reference to human rights, vulnerability or key populations, and focused largely on resource mobilization, strengthening health systems and responding to COVID-19, UNDP proposed inclusion of the following language in the final report that will be presented to the Heads of States meeting: ‘Participants highlighted the importance of ensuring equity and leaving no one behind, engaging communities fully and effectively, promoting and protecting human rights of all and combating stigma and discrimination’. This language will be incorporated in the ‘Decision’ of AWA that recommends adoption of the AWA report by the Heads of State. In addition the Decision also includes the following language which was submitted by UNAIDS: ‘Welcomes and Endorses the New UNAIDS Global AIDS Strategy, Requests the Commission in collaborations with UNAIDS and other partners to develop a Common Position on the Global AIDS Strategy, and PLEDGE for AU Leadership at the High Level Meeting on AIDS in 2021’. UNDP and other agencies will follow up with the AUC Social Affairs Directorate to ensure retaining of this language in the final Decision document that will be adapted by the Heads of States and Governments of the African Union during the AWA Side Meeting that is annually held during the AU Summit.
1. Technical support to Countries implementing HIV programmes to 16 countries in ESA and 15 countries in WCA.

In 2021, in sub-Saharan Africa, UNDP supported a total of 15 countries in West and Central Africa and 16 countries in Eastern & Southern Africa and enabled governments, civil societies, national institutions and regional economic entities to deliver on UNDP’s portfolio on HIV, health and development (HHD). These included support through UNAIDS’ UBRAF country envelops (CEs) and business unusual funds (BUF), as well as regional support from Kingdom of Netherlands Embassy (KNE) Maputo and Government of Sweden (Sida) grants.
Selected achievements include: - In Togo, UNDP with UBRAF resources supported a study on stigma, discrimination, and violation of the rights of PLHIV and key populations. In addition, UNDP is also supporting the development of the gender, human rights and HIV and AIDS Action Plan for the period 2022-2025. - UNDP in Sierra Leone supported a national profiling assessment of PLHIV, to generate evidence for the inclusion of vulnerable PLHIV and TB patients into the national social protection schemes. - In Nigeria, UNDP provided technical support for a rapid mapping analysis of human rights and gender for key populations in the context of finalizing the HIV and TB Global Fund investment case 2021-2023. - UNDP Malawi, through Centre for Development of People (CEDEP), is supporting strengthening coordination capacities of key populations under the Diversity Forum to effectively advocate for the inclusion of key populations in policy and access to services. The support is towards advocacy at the community level through community radio stations to increase awareness among targeted communities on the protection of the well-being of KPs and creating a conducive environment at the community level to enable KPs exercise their rights. - In Lesotho, UNDP supported the Lesotho PLHIV network LENEPWHA in carrying out a stigma index study for people living with HIV/AIDS.
